title: Population living below the poverty line
technical_title: Poverty headcount ratio at national poverty lines (% of population)
summary: National poverty headcount ratio is the percentage of the population living below the national poverty lines. National estimates are based on population-weighted subgroup estimates from household surveys.
description: Poverty headcount ratio among the population is measured based on national (i.e. country-specific) poverty lines. A country may have a unique national poverty line or separate poverty lines for rural and urban areas, or for different geographic areas to reflect differences in the cost of living or sometimes to reflect differences in diets and consumption baskets. Poverty estimates at national poverty lines are computed from household survey data collected from nationally representative samples of households.
cautions: This series only includes estimates that to the best of our [the World Bank's] knowledge are reasonably comparable over time for a country. Due to differences in estimation methodologies and poverty lines, estimates should not be compared across countries.
date_of_content: Most recent data available between 1985 and 2019.
citation: Poverty Headcount Ratio at National Poverty Lines (% of Population). The World Bank. 2021. Available online at: https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SI.POV.NAHC

title: Climate Risk Index Score
technical_title: The Long-Term Climate Risk Index (CRI): from 2000 to 2019 (annual averages)
summary: Level of exposure and vulnerability to more frequent and/or more severe climatic events for which countries should prepare.
description: Indicates a level of exposure and vulnerability to more frequent and/or more severe climatic events for which countries should prepare. It analyses to what extent countries have been affected by the impacts of weather-related loss events (storms, floods, heat waves etc.). The most recent data available from 2019 and 2000-2019 were taken into account. Developed by Germanwatch analyses the quantified impacts both in terms of fatalities as well as economic losses that occurred based on data from the Munich RE NatCatSERVICE.
cautions: The index must not be mistaken for a comprehensive climate vulnerability scoring. It represents one important piece in the overall puzzle of climate related impacts and the associated vulnerabilities. The index focuses on extreme weather events such as storms, floods and heatwaves but does not take into account important slow-onset processes such as rising sea levels, glacier melting or ocean warming and acidification. It is based on past data and should not be used as a basis for a linear projection of future climate impacts. More specifically, not too far-reaching conclusions should be drawn for the purpose of political discussions regarding which country or region is the most vulnerable to climate change. Also, it is important to note that the occurrence of a single extreme event cannot be easily attributed to anthropogenic climate change. In addition, contrary to previous years, the underlying database for the calculation of the 2021 data does not include data for the United States of America.
date_of_content: The most recent data available from 2019 and 2000-2019

title: Readiness Score
technical_title: Notre Dame Global Adaptation Initiative (ND-GAIN) Country Index, Readiness
summary: Measures a country's ability to leverage investments and convert them to adaptation actions.
description: ND-GAIN measures overall readiness by considering three components  economic readiness, governance readiness and social readiness.

title: World Bank Climate Change Knowledge Portal
summary: This series of 197 climate risk country profiles offers a common platform to guide access, synthesis, and analysis of relevant country data and information on climate-related vulnerabilities and risks at multiple levels of details.
description: Sources on climate and climate related information are linked through the country profiles on-line platform, which is periodically updated to reflect the most recent publicly available climate analysis. See full metadata: https://climateknowledgeportal.worldbank.org/themes/custom/wb_cckp/resources/data/Metadata.pdf
cautions: Climate Watch shows key hazards for each country with above 5% average annual natural hazard occurrence during 1990 -2018.
